thread.title: Deal between Spark and Netflix would be 'no surprise' says analyst
thread.title_full: Deal between Spark and Netflix would be 'no surprise' says analyst

author: Tom Pullar-strecker
title: Deal between Spark and Netflix would be 'no surprise' says analyst
text:
Deal between Spark and Netflix would be 'no surprise' says analyst TOM PULLAR-STRECKER Last updated 13:44, February 24 2017 MIKE BLAKE/REUTERS 
Spark won't comment on what it may or may not do with Netflix. 
Spark isn't ruling out getting into bed with Netflix, as Sky Television talks up a deeper partnership with Vodafone outside a merger. 
Spark spokesman Andrew Pirie said it was committed to its own internet television service Lightbox, which it launched in 2014. 
But he would not "confirm or deny" speculation that a partnership was being negotiated with Netflix. 
"We are not going to comment at the moment about what we may or may not do with Netflix or any other brand – except to say the media market is evolving and we want to make sure that we are at the forefront of what our customers are looking to watch and be entertained by." 
READ MORE: 
Netflix spokesman Luke McClelland said the company didn't comment on rumour or speculation. 
Forsyth Barr analyst Blair Galpin said he would not be surprised by a partnership between the firms. 
"Our view all along has been it made more sense for Spark to do a deal with Netflix than to launch Lightbox." 
Britain's Vodafone and Netflix have a global partnership, and Vodafone NZ currently offers six-months free access to Netflix to post-paid mobile customers on two-year contracts. 
"The question is – if there is a tie-up with Spark – would it be 'exclusive' and what the nature of it would be," Galpin said. Ad Feedback 
Spark has discussed opening up Lightbox by turning it into a platform that could sell programmes owned by other television companies alongside its own content. 
However, an industry source said it would not be practical to combine the two services into a single offering. 
"For a start, you would have to agree which would be the lesser brand." 
Spark could use what it regards as a highly successful partnership with streaming music service Spotify as a model for a looser arrangement that saw the internet television services provided side-by-side. 
Spark effectively resells Spotify by bundling it for free with its higher-value mobile and broadband plans. 
A partnership between the country's largest phone company and the world's largest internet television firm might appear ironic, coming on the heels of the Commerce Commission's decision on Thursday not to clear Sky Television's planned merger with Vodafone. 
However, commission chairman Mark Berry said that its concern with the Sky/Vodafone merger was Sky Sports, and it saw the market for all other programming as "highly competitive". 
Vodafone spokeswoman Andrea Brady would not comment on a suggestion from Sky TV chief executive John Fellet that the two companies could deepen their existing partnership, outside a merger.​ 
Fellet has suggested Sky TV could still source a new generation of set-top boxes from Vodafone in Europe. 
These would receive programming over ultrafast broadband, store recorded programmes "in the cloud" rather than on a hard drive, and include a much-improved electronic programming guide (EPG) that would make it easier to discover programmes. 
Berry's comments also appear to hold the door open for Sky and Vodafone to enter into exclusive agreements to supply Sky's non-sports programming to Vodafone broadband and mobile customers. 
Sky TV and Vodafone have until 20 working days after the commission releases its detail reasons for declining the merger to decide whether to appeal the commission's decision to the High Court. 
But the prospects of an appeal are already being discounted. 
While expressing disappointment at the commission's ruling, Fellet has likened an appeal to "root canal work" and questioned what the grounds for an appeal might be. 
Galpin said an appeal could take 18 months even before any subsequent appeal to a higher court. 
Even if a legal challenge was ultimately successful, the benefits of the merger might not be there for both parties at the end of that process, given the nature of sport rights, he said. - Stuff
